title: MWFRS Wind Pressure on Low-Rise Building
problem: A one-story commercial building is being designed for wind loads on the Main Wind Force Resisting System (MWFRS). The building is located in Dallas, Texas, and has a rectangular plan dimensions of 120 ft × 80 ft with a flat roof at an eave height of 24 ft. The building has a Risk Category II classification and is located in Exposure B with a topographic factor $K_{zt} = 1.0$. Determine the design wind pressure on the windward wall using the directional procedure.
given: Basic wind speed $V = 115$ mph (from ASCE 7-16 Figure 26.5-1A for Risk Category II)
Building dimensions: 120 ft × 80 ft plan, 24 ft eave height
required: Calculate the design wind pressure ($p$) on the windward wall at the mean roof height.

solution_steps.title: Determine Velocity Pressure Coefficient $K_z$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 26.10-1, for Exposure B at height $z = 24$ ft (mean roof height for flat roof):

$K_z = 0.70$ (interpolated between 0.57 at 15 ft and 0.70 at 30 ft)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Velocity Pressure $q_z$
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 26.10-1:

$$q_z = 0.00256 \times K_z \times K_{zt} \times K_d \times K_e \times V^2$$

Where $K_d = 0.85$ (MWFRS, Table 26.6-1), $K_e = 1.0$ (sea level), $K_{zt} = 1.0$

$$q_z = 0.00256 \times 0.70 \times 1.0 \times 0.85 \times 1.0 \times (115)^2$$

$$q_z = 0.00256 \times 0.70 \times 0.85 \times 13,225 = 20.05 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Internal Pressure Coefficient $GC_{pi}$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 26.11-1, for enclosed building:

$$GC_{pi} = \pm 0.18$$

solution_steps.title: Determine External Pressure Coefficient $C_p$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Figure 27.3-1, for windward wall:

$L/B = 120/80 = 1.5$

For windward wall, $C_p = 0.8$ (constant with height per Figure 27.3-1 notes)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Wind Pressure $p$
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 27.3-1:

$$p = q_z \times G \times C_p - q_i \times GC_{pi}$$

For rigid building, $G = 0.85$ (or calculate using Section 26.11).

Assuming $G = 0.85$.

For positive internal pressure (worst case for windward wall):

$$p = 20.05 \times 0.85 \times 0.8 - 20.05 \times 0.18$$

$$p = 13.63 - 3.61 = 10.02 \text{ psf}$$

For negative internal pressure:

$$p = 20.05 \times 0.85 \times 0.8 + 20.05 \times 0.18$$

$$p = 13.63 + 3.61 = 17.24 \text{ psf}$$

final_answer: The design wind pressure on the windward wall is $17.24$ psf (controlling case with negative internal pressure). This is the pressure that should be used for MWFRS design.

title: Components & Cladding Wind Pressure on Wall
problem: Determine the design wind pressure for Components and Cladding (C&C) on the wall of an enclosed office building. The building has a mean roof height of 35 ft, is located in Miami, Florida, with a Risk Category III classification. The wall panel under consideration has an effective wind area of 50 sq ft. Use Exposure C conditions.
given: Basic wind speed $V = 170$ mph (Miami, Risk Category III, ASCE 7-16 Figure 26.5-1B)
required: Calculate the design wind pressure for C&C on the wall panel at height $z = 35$ ft.

solution_steps.title: Determine Velocity Pressure Coefficient $K_z$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 26.10-1, for Exposure C at height $z = 35$ ft:

$$K_z = 1.01$$ (interpolated between 0.98 at 30 ft and 1.03 at 40 ft)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Velocity Pressure $q_h$
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 26.10-1:

$$q_h = 0.00256 \times K_z \times K_{zt} \times K_d \times K_e \times V^2$$

Where $K_d = 0.85$ (C&C, Table 26.6-1), $K_e = 1.0$

$$q_h = 0.00256 \times 1.01 \times 1.0 \times 0.85 \times 1.0 \times (170)^2$$

$$q_h = 0.00256 \times 1.01 \times 0.85 \times 28,900 = 63.36 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Effective Wind Area
solution_steps.content:
Given $A = 50$ sq ft.

Note: For C&C, if $A < 10$ sq ft, use $A = 10$ sq ft minimum.

Here, $A = 50$ sq ft.

solution_steps.title: Determine External Pressure Coefficients $GC_p$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Figure 30.3-1, for walls of enclosed buildings.

For effective wind area = 50 sq ft, interpolate between values:

**Zone 4 (wall interior):**
- $GC_p(positive) = 0.91$
- $GC_p(negative) = -1.05$

**Zone 5 (wall edges/corners):**
- $GC_p(positive) = 0.91$
- $GC_p(negative) = -1.33$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Wind Pressure
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 30.3-1:

$$p = q_h \times (GC_p - GC_{pi})$$

For enclosed building, $GC_{pi} = \pm 0.18$

**For Zone 4 interior wall:**

$$p(positive \ external + negative \ internal) = 63.36 \times (0.91 - (-0.18))$$

$$= 63.36 \times 1.09 = 69.1 \text{ psf}$$

$$p(negative \ external + positive \ internal) = 63.36 \times (-1.05 - 0.18)$$

$$= 63.36 \times (-1.23) = -77.9 \text{ psf}$$

final_answer: The design wind pressures for C&C on the wall panel are $+69.1$ psf (positive/inward) and $-77.9$ psf (negative/outward). The controlling pressure for design is $77.9$ psf outward suction.

title: Wind Pressure on Gable Roof Building
problem: A two-story industrial warehouse building is being designed for wind loads. The building has a gable roof with a slope of 4:12 (18.4°). Building dimensions are 150 ft × 100 ft in plan, with eave height of 28 ft and roof peak at 35 ft. The building is located in Houston, Texas, Risk Category II, Exposure C. Calculate the net design wind pressure on the windward roof slope.
given: Basic wind speed $V = 140$ mph (Houston, Risk Category II)
required: Calculate the design wind pressure on the windward roof slope.

solution_steps.title: Determine Velocity Pressure Coefficient $K_h$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 26.10-1, for Exposure C at mean roof height $h = 31.5$ ft:

$$K_h = 0.99$$ (interpolated between 0.98 at 30 ft and 1.03 at 40 ft)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Velocity Pressure $q_h$
solution_steps.content:
$$q_h = 0.00256 \times K_h \times K_{zt} \times K_d \times K_e \times V^2$$

$$q_h = 0.00256 \times 0.99 \times 1.0 \times 0.85 \times 1.0 \times (140)^2$$

$$q_h = 0.00256 \times 0.99 \times 0.85 \times 19,600 = 42.17 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Gust Effect Factor $G$
solution_steps.content:
For rigid building (fundamental natural frequency $\geq 1$ Hz), use $G = 0.85$ from Section 26.11.

Alternatively, calculate using equation 26.11-6 for flexible buildings.

solution_steps.title: Determine External Pressure Coefficient $C_p$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Figure 27.3-1, for gable roof with $\theta = 18.4°$ and wind normal to ridge:

For windward roof slope, use interpolation between values for $\theta = 10°$ ($C_p = -0.7$ to $-0.3$ depending on building width) and $\theta = 30°$ ($C_p = -0.5$ or $+0.2$).

For this building, $L/B = 150/100 = 1.5$

At $\theta = 18.4°$, interpolating:

$$C_p \approx -0.23$$ for windward roof (Zone 1)

Note: The pressure coefficient varies with building aspect ratio and roof angle.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Net Design Wind Pressure
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 27.3-1:

$$p = q_h \times G \times C_p - q_i \times GC_{pi}$$

For roof, use $GC_{pi} = \pm 0.18$ (enclosed building).

**Case 1 (external + internal negative):**
$$p = 42.17 \times 0.85 \times (-0.23) - 42.17 \times (-0.18)$$
$$p = -8.24 + 7.59 = -0.65 \text{ psf}$$

**Case 2 (external + internal positive):**
$$p = 42.17 \times 0.85 \times (-0.23) - 42.17 \times (0.18)$$
$$p = -8.24 - 7.59 = -15.83 \text{ psf}$$

final_answer: The design wind pressure on the windward roof slope ranges from $-0.65$ psf to $-15.83$ psf. The controlling negative pressure is $15.83$ psf (uplift). Note: Positive pressure on the windward roof occurs at higher roof angles ($\theta > \sim 22°$), but at $18.4°$, the net pressure is negative (uplift).

title: Parapet Wind Pressure Design
problem: A 15-story office building has a roof height of 180 ft with a 4-ft tall solid parapet around the entire perimeter. The building is located in Boston, Massachusetts, Risk Category II, Exposure B. Determine the design wind pressure for the parapet using MWFRS procedure. The parapet is considered part of the MWFRS.
given: Basic wind speed $V = 128$ mph (Boston, Risk Category II)
required: Calculate the MWFRS design wind pressure on the windward parapet.

solution_steps.title: Determine Velocity Pressure Coefficient
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 26.10-1, for Exposure B at height $z = 184$ ft:

$$K_z = 1.43$$ (interpolated between 1.39 at 160 ft and 1.50 at 200 ft)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Velocity Pressure $q_p$
solution_steps.content:
$$q_p = 0.00256 \times K_z \times K_{zt} \times K_d \times K_e \times V^2$$

$$q_p = 0.00256 \times 1.43 \times 1.0 \times 0.85 \times 1.0 \times (128)^2$$

$$q_p = 0.00256 \times 1.43 \times 0.85 \times 16,384 = 51.13 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Parapet Pressure Coefficients
solution_steps.content:
Per ASCE 7-16 Section 27.3.4, the net pressure coefficient for parapets is:

$$C_{p,net} = GC_p = \pm 1.5$$ for windward parapet (load case A).

The pressure acts on the parapet surface facing the wind.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Pressure on Parapet
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 27.3-3:

$$p = q_p \times (GC_{pn})$$

For MWFRS, the pressure coefficient for parapet includes both external and internal effects combined.

$$p = 51.13 \times 1.5 = 76.7 \text{ psf}$$

This pressure acts on the projected area of the parapet.

solution_steps.title: Determine Force on Parapet
solution_steps.content:
The parapet force per linear foot:

$$F = p \times h_p = 76.7 \text{ psf} \times 4 \text{ ft} = 306.8 \text{ lb/ft}$$

This force acts at the centroid of the parapet (2 ft above roof level).

final_answer: The design wind pressure on the windward parapet is $76.7$ psf. This results in a wind force of $307$ lb per linear foot of parapet, acting at the parapet's centroid (2 ft above roof level). This force must be transferred to the roof diaphragm and MWFRS.
